replies.bodyText:
I agree but we have to take into account the following:

That source code is also in WorkerSinkTask class.
ConfigDef.parseType does not trim the split. I mean, the result of splitting "topic1,topic2          " is not the same that " topic1        ,topic2".

I could include the changes you comment in this class and also in the WorkerSinkTask to be aligned. On the other hand, I would also fix the trim thing in ConfigDef.parseType(or maybe in another PR).
What do you think?
replies.author: mmolimar

replies.bodyText:
I think ConfigDef::parseType does do the trimming: 
  
    
      kafka/clients/src/main/java/org/apache/kafka/common/config/ConfigDef.java
    
    
         Line 705
      in
      9bc96d5
    
    
    
    

        
          
           return Arrays.asList(COMMA_WITH_WHITESPACE.split(trimmed, -1)); 
        
    
  


Changing the WorkerSinkTask to align seems fine, although if we're reusing this logic all over the place it might make sense to just add a utility method like parseTopicsList(Map<String, Object>) to something like the SinkConnectorConfig class that grabs the value for SinkTask.TOPICS_CONFIG, passes it to ConfigDef::parseType, and returns the result. That way we can just use that whenever we need to parse a topics list from a sink connector config.
replies.author: C0urante

replies.bodyText: ConfigDef.parseType does a trim but for the whole string, not the splits. This would be the issue in case you have spaces in each splitted topic name.
replies.author: mmolimar

replies.bodyText: I think it does do trimming for the splits, based on the regex that's used for the splitting. I tried out a few local examples and they seemed to confirm this; parsing something like " \t foo \t, \tbar\t , b a z " returned the list ["foo", "bar", "b a z"] for me.
replies.author: C0urante

replies.bodyText: Sorry about that. You're totally right.
replies.author: mmolimar

replies.bodyText: Haha, no worries! Does adding this logic to a reusable place like the SinkConnectorConfig sound good to you?

timeline.body: Is this necessary? Doesn't seem like it actually breaks anything if the user specifies duplicate topics. And if we do want to enforce constraints about non-empty topics and/or no duplicated topics, we can do that with a `Validator` for that property when it's [defined in the ConfigDef](https://github.com/apache/kafka/blob/9bc96d54f8953d190a1fb6478a0656f049ee3b32/connect/runtime/src/main/java/org/apache/kafka/connect/runtime/SinkConnectorConfig.java#L68).
